replies.author: @StrayChoom
replies.text:
They have a National Assembly it‚Äôs basically the socialist equivalent of a parliamentary system. 

The Wikipedia page in English is misleading on this, the only citations are Associated press and the BBC. 

Completely bunk sources on this matter, they have been caught red handed spreading misinformation about the DPRK before, several times.

From DPRK-based souces, it‚Äôs pretty much just stated to be a relatively normal parliamentary system. 

There‚Äôs a little modularisation and it‚Äôs more focused on the local than the state level.

Just capitalist parties are more or less banned, or esoteric, the same way that socialist parties don‚Äôt have much relevance/are outright banned in the west.

Kim Jong Un is more like prince harry to England. Just an honored celebrity for the Kim family‚Äôs role in the founding of the DPRK. Not an actual state leader, though often speaks for the country. 

Most expats from the DPRK, simply state that they left for economic reasons. 

Which would make sense because the DPRK is heavily sanctioned, and it is still technically a developing nation.

Though it has made tons of progress in the last few decades, so many people who are there are proud of the strides and progress their country has been making, in spite of adversity from the west.

replies.author: @ClassWarMatrix
replies.text:
@stray All of your replies and mine seem to be posted fine.
You can tell if it did by tracking the replies counter of a comment.
If it the counter updates +1 but then goes back -1 a minute later,   that means it was soft snatched,  and can still be viewed if sorting comments by "newest first".
(You can also post a "test" comment @ someone,  then edit it 10 minutes later and paste your actual comment,  and it will still appear in their inbox despite being snatched).
But if the counter never updates +1 after posting,  that means it was hard snatched and can't be viewed anywhere or edited.

Anyway.
Culture and spirit are material,  they matter,  to individuals and to collectives and to societies,  and very much so.
Social conservatism is not necessarily materialist or anti-materialist,  but it is a material reality experienced by people on a social level.

Strausserism as in Leo Strauss ?
I don't believe anything I'm saying is fundamentally rooted in Strauss.

Here's comrade Jiang Zemin:
"Material poverty is not socialism, and neither is spiritual emptiness. Socialism not only enriches people's material lives, but also uplifts them spiritually. Some Party members and cadres, including leading cadres, pursue and imitate the Western decadent lifestyle, worship money and are hedonistic. This is very dangerous. In Western countries today, some statesmen and insightful people are deeply troubled by Western social problems, such as widespread hedonism, degenerate thinking and spiritual decadence. A book by an American author  entitled   Social Problems in the Western World   states that the theoretical basis of Western freedom is hedonism;  that is, the purpose of life is the pursuit of sensual pleasure."

I believe Kim il Sung has written similar things.
Lenin was also not a big fan of the latest "trendy" cosmopolitan & exhibitionist cultural tendencies of his time,  which he traced back to bourgeois culture

replies.author: @StrayChoom
replies.text:
@ClassWarMatrix‚Äã‚Äã‚Å†‚Äã‚Å†socialism would innately uplift the spirit of the proletariat. I agree with that. 

And culture can be important under certain circumstances, I‚Äôm aware in Vietnam the culture itself is heavily inspired by the cultural freedom provided by socialist revolution.

Socialism was the only way to sustain Vietnamese culture. That was something important to them. Historical, spiritual almost.  
It was protection of their culture against imperialists that wanted to destroy it, that motivated many Vietnamese people into revolutionary socialism.

And even Marx wrote how bourgeois power leaves proletarians without a nation, without a culture. It just leaves them exploited.

I‚Äôm British so we do have some culture & customs. Outside of the imperialist dominance, exploitation & xenophobia. There is something beneath it.

Americans on the other hand, have nothing but vague notions. Their only culture is the dollar. Their ‚Äúculture‚Äù was born from genocide, war, greed and slavery. And the culture has not changed to this day.

Though equally I would never turn on my LGBTQ friends. Solidarity is important in that sense as focus on such issues, these people are merely proletarians and with the proletariats emancipation, follows their emancipation in the same vein.

It is also true that Marx or Engels stated (well cited an earlier socialist thinker in agreement),  the emancipation of women is an appropriate measure for the emancipation of the proletariat. 

And that reactionary sentiment should dutifully be fought against. 

All that said, though I agree with the aspect, that socialism would uplift spirit and culture. 
In my eyes, I would add two caveats, that the culture, such as American culture might be better off altered, or evolved into a something beyond the violent settler colonial culture America has. 

Which in all fairness it likely would naturally evolve upon the removal of class antagonisms from the dynamic.

And I remain firm I do not consider spirituality to be material either. That is something metaphysical which materialists reject. The value it has is social value for some proletarians. 

And some bourgeois. So it has as a social phenomena, it is closely tied with the superstructure standing atop the productive base of society. 
And it is changes in the mode of production that influence social change, more than the other way around.

Culture and spirituality are something of value that socialism would protect & uplift , but the whole philosophical point of communism from the Marxist perspective is leisure  & happiness over duty. 

Which is given as the basis of freedom. 

So the specific rejection of hedonism strikes me as interesting.  
Not necessarily that I disagree, hedonism runs downwind of consumerism. It‚Äôs not healthy on the individual level or the social level. 

But what would be considered hedonism, is a matter of perspective.

One of  Marx‚Äôs main inspirations  outside  of  Hegel was Epicureanism, an ancient philosophy that focused on individual happiness through friendship.  
And Marx also echoed this sentiment in pieces like wage labour capital and critique of the Gotha programme.  

With that comes the woman question, (real thing) and the question of freedom from social expectation (my question). In the case of what would be considered ‚Äútrue emancipation‚Äù.
 
As far as the strausserite comment, it was more of a‚Ä¶ ‚Äúvibe‚Äù. 
An exercise in vibes based analysis. It was the only word I could think of. I was basically asking if you consider yourself a third positionist or not.

Because though I do not call myself ‚Äúleft‚Äù I say I am a communist. But I do consider myself to be ‚Äúfar left‚Äù and not necessarily a third positionist.

For example Mussolini in the doctrine of fascism talked extensively about the ‚Äúprofound degradation of culture‚Äù and ‚Äúspiritual crisis‚Äù. So the overlap here is something that seemed markedly odd, as it‚Äôs not the language a Leninist would use.

Which is where the third positionist question comes in. 
Because I wouldn‚Äôt register you as a simple Leninist. You didn‚Äôt cite Lenin as a reply üòÇ

Though I‚Äôm not calling you a fascist merely that there were some things that I noticed that had overlap with what Mussolini wrote in the doctrine of fascism.

But now I mostly understand the context of what you were saying. Though I‚Äôm still skeptical of reactionary views. But ultimately I agree with most of what you‚Äôre saying comrade.

author: @ZionistBourgeoisie
text:
What do you mean "the institutions highest of which should be the state"

"The proletariat needs the state" ‚Äî this phrase is repeated by all opportunists, social-chauvinists, and Kautskyites, who assure us that this is what Marx taught.
But they conveniently ‚Äúforget‚Äù to add two essential points:
First, according to Marx, the proletariat needs only a state that is already withering away‚Äîthat is, a state so constituted that it begins to wither away immediately, and cannot help but wither away.
Second, the working people need a state, that is, the proletariat organized as the ruling class.

The state is a special organization of force‚Äîan organization of violence designed for the suppression of a particular class.

-State and Revolution, Vladimir Lenin (page 24)

replies.author: @ClassWarMatrix
replies.text:
@dylan 1. I don't think you know what oligarchy means.
Money doesn't dictate or determine the content of DPRK's politics or government.
In cases where it does,  it is corruption,  and is punished ruthlessly.

You don't need to be associated with the Kim family in order to achieve a high standing in military or government,  or to have upward mobility in society.

2. Juche is derivative of Marxism-Leninism.
It is a new synthesis of ML that corresponds to the material conditions of Korea and the national context of Korea,  similar to 'socialism with Chinese characteristics'.

ML is a living science which is constantly evolving.
It's not a platonic ideal,  it's not a static form.

3. You're not thinking dialectically about political-economy.
The working class never directly holds state power and they never directly administer society.
Because they're busy working.
It is the job of statesmen and sovereigns to wield power in the interests of the masses (in the interests of general labor,  in the case of Communist states).
In DPRK there are direct means through which workers and ordinary people influence the state,  and they do this through the party,  through their enterprises & workplaces,  and through other collective organizations.
But they don't directly preside over state organs.
And neither can Kim Jong Un just do whatever he wants willy nilly at his own personal behest.

The WPK holds power at the behest of a popular mandate from workers.  Not at the behest of oligarchs and landowners and bourgeoisie.
If DPRK was run by oligarchs, it would've long either collapsed,  or sold out to Western banks--  as is the dominant tendency of oligarchs in the 21st century.

author: @LewisSmith-f2q
text: It seems to me that North Korea embodies a form of independence rarely acknowledged. The nation is self sufficient, untainted by Western consumerism, and maintains a social order that prioritises collective stability over individual indulgence. Access to pornography is prohibited, a measure that protects mental clarity rather than erodes freedom. Citizens benefit from clean water, universal services, and a society where homelessness is virtually absent. The country has been spared terrorism, foreign wars, and the cultural dislocation that often accompanies imported values. In this sense, one might argue that North Korea represents a model of social progress defined not by Western metrics but by its own sovereign ideals.

text: North Korea is not a socialist state in any meaningful sense. The regime has long mimicked socialist rhetoric and symbolism, primarily because it was politically convenient ‚Äî wrapping itself in the red flag to secure aid from the declining Soviet Union in its final years. Today, this mimicry persists mainly to ensure continued support from China. However, the red banners and stars merely conceal what is, in essence, an archaic feudal monarchy. The Kim dynasty has no intention of building communism; there is no socialism in practice. The entire economy functions as the private property of the ruling family, while the North Korean people live as their indentured laborers.

replies.author: @servusprotervus6463
replies.text:
@fineproductions18929 Based on a materialist understanding of the world, nothing is static: matter exists in a state of constant motion, change, and development. This fully applies to society as well. From the standpoint of historical materialism, socio-economic formations are not frozen structures but historically variable forms of organizing social production, existing in a process of continuous development.

Like any complex form of organized matter, society develops through internal contradictions. As these contradictions accumulate, quantitative changes inevitably lead to qualitative leaps, expressed in the transition from one socio-economic formation to another. Therefore, society cannot remain indefinitely in the same state: each formation has a historically limited character.

Each subsequent socio-economic formation does not arise out of nothing, but on the basis of material and social preconditions created within the framework of the preceding one. Thus, the slave-owning formation emerged as a result of the disintegration of the primitive communal system, alongside the growth of productive forces and the appearance of surplus product, which made the exploitation of man by man possible. The feudal formation took shape in the process of crisis and disintegration of slave-owning society, relying on the inherited material base while constructing different relations of production. Capitalism, in turn, arose on the foundation of feudal society, making use of the productive forces accumulated in previous epochs and radically transforming forms of property and the organization of labor.

Thus, historical materialism provides no grounds for viewing any socio-economic formation as final or immutable.
